The Rome Statute grants the ICC jurisdiction over alleged crimes committed in member states that have ratified the statute, as well as over crimes referred to the Court by the United Nations Security Council. In the case of the ICC's investigation of crimes in Palestinian Territories, the Rome Statute provides jurisdiction over the alleged crimes committed in those territories. [2, 4, 9]

The ICC's investigation of crimes committed in the Palestinian territories focuses on alleged crimes within the jurisdiction of the Court that are alleged to have been committed in the occupied Palestinian territory; ICC-01/18; ICC's mandate is to investigate crimes in cases where states are unable or unwilling to investigate themselves. The ICC has authority to investigate and prosecute individuals for crimes in the Palestinian territories. It has jurisdiction over the territory of Palestine and has initiated an investigation into alleged war crimes committed by Israeli or Palestinian individuals; [0, 3, 4, 7].

The ICC's investigation of crimes in the Palestinian territories has faced criticisms related to its jurisdiction and authority, as well as concerns about fairness and the singling out of Israel.
